castItem.roleDesc: proprietor of an inn in Milan
living in a forest near Mantua

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Cease to persuade , my loving Proteus .
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits .
Were ’t not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honored love ,
I rather would entreat thy company
To see the wonders of the world abroad
Than , living dully sluggardized at home ,
Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness .
But since thou lov’st , love still and thrive therein ,
Even as I would when I to love begin .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone ? Sweet Valentine , adieu .
Think on thy Proteus when thou haply seest
Some rare noteworthy object in thy travel .
Wish me partaker in thy happiness
When thou dost meet good hap ; and in thy danger ,
If ever danger do environ thee ,
Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers ,
For I will be thy beadsman , Valentine .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: And on a love-book pray for my success ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Upon some book I love I’ll pray for thee .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: That’s on some shallow story of deep love ,
How young Leander crossed the Hellespont .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: That’s a deep story of a deeper love ,
For he was more than over shoes in love .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: ’Tis true , for you are over boots in love ,
And yet you never swam the Hellespont .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Over the boots ? Nay , give me not the boots .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No , I will not , for it boots thee not .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: What ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: To be in love , where scorn is bought with groans ,
Coy looks with heart-sore sighs , one fading moment’s mirth
With twenty watchful , weary , tedious nights ;
If haply won , perhaps a hapless gain ;
If lost , why then a grievous labor won ;
How ever , but a folly bought with wit ,
Or else a wit by folly vanquishèd .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: So , by your circumstance , you call me fool .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: So , by your circumstance , I fear you’ll prove .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: ’Tis love you cavil at ; I am not Love .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Love is your master , for he masters you ;
And he that is so yokèd by a fool
Methinks should not be chronicled for wise .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Yet writers say : as in the sweetest bud
The eating canker dwells , so eating love
Inhabits in the finest wits of all .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: And writers say : as the most forward bud
Is eaten by the canker ere it blow ,
Even so by love the young and tender wit
Is turned to folly , blasting in the bud ,
Losing his verdure , even in the prime ,
And all the fair effects of future hopes .
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee
That art a votary to fond desire ?
Once more adieu . My father at the road
Expects my coming , there to see me shipped .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: And thither will I bring thee , Valentine .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Sweet Proteus , no . Now let us take our leave .
To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
Of thy success in love , and what news else
Betideth here in absence of thy friend .
And I likewise will visit thee with mine .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: As much to you at home . And so farewell .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: He after honor hunts , I after love .
He leaves his friends , to dignify them more ;
I leave myself , my friends , and all , for love .
Thou , Julia , thou hast metamorphosed me ,
Made me neglect my studies , lose my time ,
War with good counsel , set the world at nought ;
Made wit with musing weak , heart sick with thought .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Sir Proteus , ’save you . Saw you my master ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: But now he parted hence to embark for Milan .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Twenty to one , then , he is shipped already ,
And I have played the sheep in losing him .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Indeed a sheep doth very often stray ,
An if the shepherd be awhile away .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: You conclude that my master is a shepherd ,
then , and I a sheep ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I do .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , then my horns are his horns , whether I
wake or sleep .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: A silly answer , and fitting well a sheep .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: This proves me still a sheep .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: True , and thy master a shepherd .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Nay , that I can deny by a circumstance .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: It shall go hard but I’ll prove it by another .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: The shepherd seeks the sheep , and not the
sheep the shepherd ; but I seek my master , and my
master seeks not me . Therefore I am no sheep .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd ; the
shepherd for food follows not the sheep . Thou for
wages followest thy master ; thy master for wages
follows not thee . Therefore thou art a sheep .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Such another proof will make me cry “ baa . ”

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: But dost thou hear ? Gav’st thou my letter to
Julia ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Ay , sir . I , a lost mutton , gave your letter to her , a
laced mutton , and she , a laced mutton , gave me , a
lost mutton , nothing for my labor .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Here’s too small a pasture for such store of
muttons .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: If the ground be overcharged , you were best
stick her .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Nay , in that you are astray ; ’twere best pound
you .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Nay , sir , less than a pound shall serve me for
carrying your letter .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: You mistake ; I mean the pound , a pinfold .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: From a pound to a pin ? Fold it over and over ,
’Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your lover .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: But what said she ?

sp.speaker: SPEED , nodding
sp.l: Ay .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Nod — “ Ay . ” Why , that’s “ noddy . ”

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: You mistook , sir . I say she did nod , and you ask
me if she did nod , and I say “ ay . ”

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: And that set together is “ noddy . ”

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Now you have taken the pains to set it together ,
take it for your pains .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: No , no , you shall have it for bearing the letter .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Well , I perceive I must be fain to bear with you .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Why , sir , how do you bear with me ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Marry , sir , the letter , very orderly , having nothing
but the word “ noddy ” for my pains .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Beshrew me , but you have a quick wit .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Come , come , open the matter in brief . What
said she ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Open your purse , that the money and the matter
may be both at once delivered .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS , giving money
sp.l: Well , sir , here is for your
pains . What said she ?

sp.speaker: SPEED , looking at the money
sp.l: Truly , sir , I think you’ll
hardly win her .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Why ? Couldst thou perceive so much from
her ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Sir , I could perceive nothing at all from her , no ,
not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter .
And being so hard to me that brought your mind , I
fear she’ll prove as hard to you in telling your mind .
Give her no token but stones , for she’s as hard as
steel .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: What said she ? Nothing ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: No , not so much as “ Take this for thy pains . ”
To testify your bounty , I thank you , you have
testerned me . In requital whereof , henceforth
carry your letters yourself . And so , sir , I’ll commend
you to my master .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Go , go , begone , to save your ship from wrack ,
Which cannot perish having thee aboard ,
Being destined to a drier death on shore .
I must go send some better messenger .
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines ,
Receiving them from such a worthless post .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: But say , Lucetta , now we are alone ,
Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Ay , madam , so you stumble not unheedfully .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
That every day with parle encounter me ,
In thy opinion which is worthiest love ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Please you repeat their names , I’ll show my mind
According to my shallow simple skill .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: What think’st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: As of a knight well-spoken , neat , and fine ;
But , were I you , he never should be mine .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: What think’st thou of the rich Mercatio ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Well of his wealth , but of himself so-so .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: What think’st thou of the gentle Proteus ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Lord , Lord , to see what folly reigns in us !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: How now ? What means this passion at his name ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Pardon , dear madam , ’tis a passing shame
That I , unworthy body as I am ,
Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Why not on Proteus , as of all the rest ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Then thus : of many good , I think him best .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Your reason ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: I have no other but a woman’s reason :
I think him so because I think him so .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Ay , if you thought your love not cast away .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Why , he of all the rest hath never moved me .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Yet he of all the rest I think best loves you .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: His little speaking shows his love but small .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Fire that’s closest kept burns most of all .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: They do not love that do not show their love .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: O , they love least that let men know their love .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: I would I knew his mind .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA , handing her a paper
sp.l: Peruse this paper , madam .

sp.speaker: JULIA reads
sp.l: “ To Julia . ” — Say from whom .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: That the contents will show .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Say , say who gave it thee .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Sir Valentine’s page ; and sent , I think , from Proteus .
He would have given it you , but I , being in the way ,
Did in your name receive it . Pardon the fault , I pray .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Now , by my modesty , a goodly broker !
Dare you presume to harbor wanton lines ?
To whisper and conspire against my youth ?
Now trust me , ’tis an office of great worth ,
And you an officer fit for the place .
There , take the paper ; see it be returned ,
Or else return no more into my sight .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA , taking the paper
sp.l: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Will you be gone ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: That you may ruminate .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: And yet I would I had o’erlooked the letter .
It were a shame to call her back again
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her .
What fool is she that knows I am a maid
And would not force the letter to my view ,
Since maids in modesty say “ no ” to that
Which they would have the profferer construe “ ay ” !
Fie , fie , how wayward is this foolish love
That like a testy babe will scratch the nurse
And presently , all humbled , kiss the rod !
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence ,
When willingly I would have had her here !
How angerly I taught my brow to frown ,
When inward joy enforced my heart to smile !
My penance is to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past . —
What ho , Lucetta !

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: What would your Ladyship ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Is ’t near dinner time ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: I would it were ,
That you might kill your stomach on your meat
And not upon your maid .

stage.hi: She drops a paper and then retrieves it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: What is ’t that you took up so gingerly ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Nothing .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Why didst thou stoop , then ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: To take a paper up that I let fall .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: And is that paper nothing ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Nothing concerning me .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Then let it lie for those that it concerns .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Madam , it will not lie where it concerns
Unless it have a false interpreter .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: That I might sing it , madam , to a tune ,
Give me a note . Your Ladyship can set —

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: As little by such toys as may be possible .
Best sing it to the tune of “ Light o’ Love . ”

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: It is too heavy for so light a tune .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Heavy ? Belike it hath some burden then ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Ay , and melodious were it , would you sing it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: And why not you ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: I cannot reach so high .

sp.speaker: JULIA , taking the paper
sp.l: Let’s see your song . How now , minion !

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Keep tune there still , so you will sing it out .
And yet methinks I do not like this tune .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: You do not ?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: No , madam , ’tis too sharp .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: You , minion , are too saucy .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Nay , now you are too flat
And mar the concord with too harsh a descant .
There wanteth but a mean to fill your song .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: The mean is drowned with your unruly bass .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Indeed , I bid the base for Proteus .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me .
Here is a coil with protestation .

stage.hi: She rips up the paper . Lucetta begins to pick up the pieces .

sp.l: Go , get you gone , and let the papers lie .
You would be fing’ring them to anger me .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: She makes it strange , but she would be best pleased
To be so angered with another letter .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Nay , would I were so angered with the same !
O hateful hands , to tear such loving words !
Injurious wasps , to feed on such sweet honey
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings !
I’ll kiss each several paper for amends .
Look , here is writ “ kind Julia . ” Unkind Julia ,
As in revenge of thy ingratitude ,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones ,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain .
And here is writ “ love-wounded Proteus . ”
Poor wounded name , my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly healed ,
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss .
But twice or thrice was “ Proteus ” written down .
Be calm , good wind . Blow not a word away
Till I have found each letter in the letter
Except mine own name . That some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged , fearful , hanging rock
And throw it thence into the raging sea .
Lo , here in one line is his name twice writ :
“ Poor forlorn Proteus , passionate Proteus ,
To the sweet Julia . ” That I’ll tear away —
And yet I will not , sith so prettily
He couples it to his complaining names .
Thus will I fold them one upon another .
Now kiss , embrace , contend , do what you will .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Madam , dinner is ready , and your father stays .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Well , let us go .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: What , shall these papers lie like telltales here ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: If you respect them , best to take them up .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Nay , I was taken up for laying them down .
Yet here they shall not lie , for catching cold .

stage.hi: She picks up the rest of the pieces .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: I see you have a month’s mind to them .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Ay , madam , you may say what sights you see ;
I see things too , although you judge I wink .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Come , come , will ’t please you go ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Tell me , Pantino , what sad talk was that
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister ?

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: ’Twas of his nephew Proteus , your son .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Why , what of him ?

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: He wondered that your Lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home
While other men , of slender reputation ,
Put forth their sons to seek preferment out :
Some to the wars to try their fortune there ,
Some to discover islands far away ,
Some to the studious universities .
For any or for all these exercises
He said that Proteus your son was meet ,
And did request me to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home ,
Which would be great impeachment to his age
In having known no travel in his youth .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Nor need’st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering .
I have considered well his loss of time
And how he cannot be a perfect man ,
Not being tried and tutored in the world .
Experience is by industry achieved
And perfected by the swift course of time .
Then tell me whither were I best to send him .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: I think your Lordship is not ignorant
How his companion , youthful Valentine ,
Attends the Emperor in his royal court .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I know it well .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: ’Twere good , I think , your Lordship sent him thither .
There shall he practice tilts and tournaments ,
Hear sweet discourse , converse with noblemen ,
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I like thy counsel . Well hast thou advised ,
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it ,
The execution of it shall make known .
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the Emperor’s court .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Tomorrow , may it please you , Don Alphonso ,
With other gentlemen of good esteem ,
Are journeying to salute the Emperor
And to commend their service to his will .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Good company . With them shall Proteus go .
And in good time ! Now will we break with him .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS , to himself
sp.l: Sweet love , sweet lines , sweet life !
Here is her hand , the agent of her heart ;
Here is her oath for love , her honor’s pawn .
O , that our fathers would applaud our loves
To seal our happiness with their consents .
O heavenly Julia !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: How now ? What letter are you reading there ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: May ’t please your Lordship , ’tis a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine ,
Delivered by a friend that came from him .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Lend me the letter . Let me see what news .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: There is no news , my lord , but that he writes
How happily he lives , how well beloved
And daily gracèd by the Emperor ,
Wishing me with him , partner of his fortune .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: And how stand you affected to his wish ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: As one relying on your Lordship’s will ,
And not depending on his friendly wish .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: My will is something sorted with his wish .
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed ,
For what I will , I will , and there an end .
I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus in the Emperor’s court .
What maintenance he from his friends receives ,
Like exhibition thou shalt have from me .
Tomorrow be in readiness to go .
Excuse it not , for I am peremptory .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: My lord , I cannot be so soon provided .
Please you deliberate a day or two .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Look what thou want’st shall be sent after thee .
No more of stay . Tomorrow thou must go . —
Come on , Pantino ; you shall be employed
To hasten on his expedition .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Thus have I shunned the fire for fear of burning
And drenched me in the sea , where I am drowned .
I feared to show my father Julia’s letter
Lest he should take exceptions to my love ,
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love .
O , how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day ,
Which now shows all the beauty of the sun ,
And by and by a cloud takes all away .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Sir Proteus , your father calls for you .
He is in haste . Therefore , I pray you , go .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Why , this it is : my heart accords thereto .
Aside . And yet a thousand times it answers “ no . ”

stage.hi: Enter Valentine and Speed , carrying a glove .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Sir , your glove .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Not mine . My gloves are on .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , then , this may be yours , for this is but one .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ha ? Let me see . Ay , give it me , it’s mine .
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine !
Ah , Sylvia , Sylvia !

sp.speaker: SPEED , calling
sp.l: Madam Sylvia ! Madam Sylvia !

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How now , sirrah ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: She is not within hearing , sir .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , sir , who bade you call her ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Your Worship , sir , or else I mistook .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Well , you’ll still be too forward .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Go to , sir . Tell me , do you know Madam
Sylvia ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: She that your Worship loves ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , how know you that I am in love ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Marry , by these special marks : first , you have
learned , like Sir Proteus , to wreathe your arms like
a malcontent ; to relish a love song like a robin
redbreast ; to walk alone like one that had the
pestilence ; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his
ABC ; to weep like a young wench that had buried
her grandam ; to fast like one that takes diet ; to
watch like one that fears robbing ; to speak puling
like a beggar at Hallowmas . You were wont , when
you laughed , to crow like a cock ; when you walked ,
to walk like one of the lions . When you fasted , it was
presently after dinner ; when you looked sadly , it
was for want of money . And now you are metamorphosed
with a mistress , that when I look on you , I
can hardly think you my master .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Are all these things perceived in me ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: They are all perceived without you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Without me ? They cannot .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Without you ? Nay , that’s certain , for without
you were so simple , none else would . But you are so
without these follies , that these follies are within
you and shine through you like the water in an
urinal , that not an eye that sees you but is a
physician to comment on your malady .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: But tell me , dost thou know my Lady
Sylvia ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Hast thou observed that ? Even she I mean .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , sir , I know her not .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her
and yet know’st her not ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Is she not hard-favored , sir ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Not so fair , boy , as well-favored .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Sir , I know that well enough .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What dost thou know ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: That she is not so fair as , of you , well-favored .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I mean that her beauty is exquisite but her
favor infinite .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: That’s because the one is painted , and the other
out of all count .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How painted ? And how out of count ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Marry , sir , so painted to make her fair , that no
man counts of her beauty .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How esteem’st thou me ? I account of her
beauty .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: You never saw her since she was deformed .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How long hath she been deformed ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Ever since you loved her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I have loved her ever since I saw her , and
still I see her beautiful .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: If you love her , you cannot see her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Because love is blind . O , that you had mine eyes ,
or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to
have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going
ungartered !

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What should I see then ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Your own present folly and her passing deformity ;
for he , being in love , could not see to garter his
hose , and you , being in love , cannot see to put on
your hose .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Belike , boy , then you are in love , for last
morning you could not see to wipe my shoes .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: True , sir , I was in love with my bed . I thank you ,
you swinged me for my love , which makes me the
bolder to chide you for yours .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: In conclusion , I stand affected to her .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: I would you were set , so your affection would
cease .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Last night she enjoined me to write some
lines to one she loves .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And have you ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I have .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Are they not lamely writ ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No , boy , but as well as I can do them .
Peace , here she comes .

sp.speaker: SPEED , aside
sp.l: O excellent motion ! O exceeding puppet !
Now will he interpret to her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Madam and mistress , a thousand
good-morrows .

sp.speaker: SPEED , aside
sp.l: O , give ye good ev’n ! Here’s a million of
manners .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Sir Valentine , and servant , to you two
thousand .

sp.speaker: SPEED , aside
sp.l: He should give her interest , and she
gives it him .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: As you enjoined me , I have writ your letter
Unto the secret , nameless friend of yours ,
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in
But for my duty to your Ladyship .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: I thank you , gentle servant , ’tis very clerkly done .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Now trust me , madam , it came hardly off ,
For , being ignorant to whom it goes ,
I writ at random , very doubtfully .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Perchance you think too much of so much pains ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No , madam . So it stead you , I will write ,
Please you command , a thousand times as much ,
And yet —

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: A pretty period . Well , I guess the sequel ;
And yet I will not name it And yet I care not .
And yet take this again .
And yet I thank you ,
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more .

sp.speaker: SPEED , aside
sp.l: And yet you will ; and yet another “ yet . ”

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What means your Ladyship ? Do you not like it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Yes , yes , the lines are very quaintly writ ,
But , since unwillingly , take them again .
Nay , take them .

stage.hi: She again offers him the paper .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Madam , they are for you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Ay , ay . You writ them , sir , at my request ,
But I will none of them . They are for you .
I would have had them writ more movingly .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE , taking the paper
sp.l: Please you , I’ll write your Ladyship another .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: And when it’s writ , for my sake read it over ,
And if it please you , so ; if not , why , so .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: If it please me , madam ? What then ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Why , if it please you , take it for your labor .
And so good-morrow , servant .

sp.speaker: SPEED , aside
sp.l: O jest unseen , inscrutable , invisible
As a nose on a man’s face , or a weathercock on a steeple !
My master sues to her , and she hath taught her suitor ,
He being her pupil , to become her tutor .
O excellent device ! Was there ever heard a better ?
That my master , being scribe , to himself should write the letter ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How now , sir ? What , are you reasoning
with yourself ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Nay , I was rhyming . ’Tis you that have the
reason .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: To do what ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: To be a spokesman from Madam Sylvia .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: To whom ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: To yourself . Why , she woos you by a figure .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What figure ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: By a letter , I should say .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , she hath not writ to me !

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: What need she when she hath made you write
to yourself ? Why , do you not perceive the jest ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No , believe me .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: No believing you indeed , sir . But did you perceive
her earnest ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: She gave me none , except an angry word .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , she hath given you a letter .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: That’s the letter I writ to her friend .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And that letter hath she delivered , and there an
end .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I would it were no worse .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: I’ll warrant you , ’tis as well .

lg.l: For often have you writ to her , and she , in modesty
Or else for want of idle time , could not again reply ,
Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover ,
Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover .

sp.l: All this I speak in print , for in print I found it . Why
muse you , sir ? ’Tis dinnertime .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I have dined .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Ay , but hearken , sir , though the chameleon love
can feed on the air , I am one that am nourished by
my victuals and would fain have meat . O , be not like
your mistress ! Be moved , be moved .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Have patience , gentle Julia .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: I must where is no remedy .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: When possibly I can , I will return .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: If you turn not , you will return the sooner .
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia’s sake .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS , giving her a ring
sp.l: Why , then we’ll make exchange . Here , take you this .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Here is my hand for my true constancy .
And when that hour o’erslips me in the day
Wherein I sigh not , Julia , for thy sake ,
The next ensuing hour some foul mischance
Torment me for my love’s forgetfulness .
My father stays my coming . Answer not .
The tide is now — nay , not thy tide of tears ;
That tide will stay me longer than I should .
Julia , farewell .
What , gone without a word ?
Ay , so true love should do . It cannot speak ,
For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Sir Proteus , you are stayed for .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Go . I come , I come .
Aside . Alas , this parting strikes poor lovers dumb .

stage.hi: Enter Lance , weeping , with his dog , Crab .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Nay , ’twill be this hour ere I have done weeping .
All the kind of the Lances have this very fault . I have
received my proportion like the Prodigious Son and
am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial’s court . I
think Crab my dog be the sourest-natured dog that
lives : my mother weeping , my father wailing , my
sister crying , our maid howling , our cat wringing
her hands , and all our house in a great perplexity ,
yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed one tear . He
is a stone , a very pibble stone , and has no more pity
in him than a dog . A Jew would have wept to have
seen our parting . Why , my grandam , having no
eyes , look you , wept herself blind at my parting .
Nay , I’ll show you the manner of it .
This shoe is my father . No , this left shoe is
my father ; no , no , this left shoe is my mother . Nay ,
that cannot be so neither . Yes , it is so , it is so ; it hath
the worser sole . This shoe with the hole in it is my
mother ; and this my father . A vengeance on ’t , there
’tis ! Now sir , this staff is my sister , for , look you , she
is as white as a lily and as small as a wand . This hat
is Nan , our maid . I am the dog . No , the dog is
himself , and I am the dog . O , the dog is me , and I
am myself . Ay , so , so . Now come I to my father :
“ Father , your blessing . ” Now should not the shoe
speak a word for weeping . Now should I kiss my
father . He kisses one shoe . Well , he weeps on . Now
come I to my mother . O , that she could speak now
like a wold woman ! Well , I kiss her .
Why , there ’tis ; here’s my mother’s
breath up and down . Now come I to my sister . Mark
the moan she makes ! Now the dog all this while
sheds not a tear nor speaks a word . But see how I
lay the dust with my tears .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Lance , away , away ! Aboard . Thy master is
shipped , and thou art to post after with oars . What’s
the matter ? Why weep’st thou , man ? Away , ass .
You’ll lose the tide if you tarry any longer .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: It is no matter if the tied were lost , for it is the
unkindest tied that ever any man tied .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: What’s the unkindest tide ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , he that’s tied here , Crab my dog .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Tut , man . I mean thou ’lt lose the flood and , in
losing the flood , lose thy voyage and , in losing thy
voyage , lose thy master and , in losing thy master ,
lose thy service and , in losing thy service —
Why dost thou stop my
mouth ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Where should I lose my tongue ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: In thy tale .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: In thy tail !

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Lose the tide , and the voyage , and the master ,
and the service , and the tied . Why , man , if the river
were dry , I am able to fill it with my tears ; if the
wind were down , I could drive the boat with my
sighs .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Come . Come away , man . I was sent to call
thee .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Sir , call me what thou dar’st .

sp.speaker: PANTINO
sp.l: Wilt thou go ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Well , I will go .

stage.hi: Enter Valentine , Sylvia , Thurio , and Speed .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Servant !

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Mistress ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Master , Sir Thurio frowns on you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , boy , it’s for love .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Not of you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Of my mistress , then .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: ’Twere good you knocked him .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA , to Valentine
sp.l: Servant , you are sad .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Indeed , madam , I seem so .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: Seem you that you are not ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Haply I do .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: So do counterfeits .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: So do you .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: What seem I that I am not ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Wise .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: What instance of the contrary ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Your folly .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: And how quote you my folly ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I quote it in your jerkin .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: My “ jerkin ” is a doublet .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Well , then , I’ll double your folly .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: How !

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: What , angry , Sir Thurio ? Do you change color ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Give him leave , madam . He is a kind of
chameleon .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: That hath more mind to feed on your blood
than live in your air .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: You have said , sir .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: Ay , sir , and done too for this time .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I know it well , sir . You always end ere you
begin .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: A fine volley of words , gentlemen , and quickly
shot off .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: ’Tis indeed , madam . We thank the giver .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Who is that , servant ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Yourself , sweet lady , for you gave the fire .
Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your Ladyship’s
looks and spends what he borrows kindly in your
company .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: Sir , if you spend word for word with me , I shall
make your wit bankrupt .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I know it well , sir . You have an exchequer
of words and , I think , no other treasure to give your
followers , for it appears by their bare liveries that
they live by your bare words .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: No more , gentlemen , no more . Here comes my father .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Now , daughter Sylvia , you are hard beset . —
Sir Valentine , your father is in good health .
What say you to a letter from your friends
Of much good news ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: My lord , I will be thankful
To any happy messenger from thence .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Know you Don Antonio , your countryman ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , my good lord , I know the gentleman
To be of worth and worthy estimation ,
And not without desert so well reputed .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Hath he not a son ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , my good lord , a son that well deserves
The honor and regard of such a father .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: You know him well ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I knew him as myself , for from our infancy
We have conversed and spent our hours together ,
And though myself have been an idle truant ,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection ,
Yet hath Sir Proteus — for that’s his name —
Made use and fair advantage of his days :
His years but young , but his experience old ;
His head unmellowed , but his judgment ripe ;
And in a word — for far behind his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow —
He is complete in feature and in mind ,
With all good grace to grace a gentleman .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Beshrew me , sir , but if he make this good ,
He is as worthy for an empress’ love ,
As meet to be an emperor’s counselor .
Well , sir , this gentleman is come to me
With commendation from great potentates ,
And here he means to spend his time awhile .
I think ’tis no unwelcome news to you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Should I have wished a thing , it had been he .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Welcome him then according to his worth .
Sylvia , I speak to you — and you , Sir Thurio .
For Valentine , I need not cite him to it .
I will send him hither to you presently .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: This is the gentleman I told your Ladyship
Had come along with me but that his mistress
Did hold his eyes locked in her crystal looks .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Nay , sure , I think she holds them prisoners still .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Nay , then , he should be blind , and being blind
How could he see his way to seek out you ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , lady , love hath twenty pair of eyes .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: They say that Love hath not an eye at all .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: To see such lovers , Thurio , as yourself .
Upon a homely object , Love can wink .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Have done , have done . Here comes the gentleman .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Welcome , dear Proteus . — Mistress , I beseech you
Confirm his welcome with some special favor .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither ,
If this be he you oft have wished to hear from .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Mistress , it is . Sweet lady , entertain him
To be my fellow-servant to your Ladyship .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: Too low a mistress for so high a servant .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Not so , sweet lady , but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy mistress .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Leave off discourse of disability .
Sweet lady , entertain him for your servant .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: My duty will I boast of , nothing else .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: And duty never yet did want his meed .
Servant , you are welcome to a worthless mistress .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I’ll die on him that says so but yourself .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: That you are welcome ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: That you are worthless .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: Madam , my lord your father would speak with you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.l: I wait upon his pleasure . Servant exits . Come , Sir Thurio ,
Go with me . — Once more , new servant , welcome .
I’ll leave you to confer of home affairs .
When you have done , we look to hear from you .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: We’ll both attend upon your Ladyship .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Now tell me , how do all from whence you came ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Your friends are well and have them much commended .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: And how do yours ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I left them all in health .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: How does your lady ? And how thrives your love ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: My tales of love were wont to weary you .
I know you joy not in a love discourse .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , Proteus , but that life is altered now .
I have done penance for contemning Love ,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punished me
With bitter fasts , with penitential groans ,
With nightly tears , and daily heartsore sighs ,
For in revenge of my contempt of love ,
Love hath chased sleep from my enthrallèd eyes
And made them watchers of mine own heart’s sorrow .
O gentle Proteus , Love’s a mighty lord
And hath so humbled me as I confess
There is no woe to his correction ,
Nor , to his service , no such joy on Earth .
Now , no discourse except it be of love .
Now can I break my fast , dine , sup , and sleep
Upon the very naked name of Love .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Enough ; I read your fortune in your eye .
Was this the idol that you worship so ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Even she . And is she not a heavenly saint ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: No , but she is an earthly paragon .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Call her divine .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I will not flatter her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: O , flatter me , for love delights in praises .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: When I was sick , you gave me bitter pills ,
And I must minister the like to you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Then speak the truth by her ; if not divine ,
Yet let her be a principality ,
Sovereign to all the creatures on the Earth .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Except my mistress .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Sweet , except not any ,
Except thou wilt except against my love .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Have I not reason to prefer mine own ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: And I will help thee to prefer her too :
She shall be dignified with this high honor —
To bear my lady’s train , lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
And , of so great a favor growing proud ,
Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower
And make rough winter everlastingly .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Why , Valentine , what braggartism is this ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Pardon me , Proteus , all I can is nothing
To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing .
She is alone —

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Then let her alone .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Not for the world ! Why , man , she is mine own ,
And I as rich in having such a jewel
As twenty seas if all their sand were pearl ,
The water nectar , and the rocks pure gold .
Forgive me that I do not dream on thee ,
Because thou seest me dote upon my love .
My foolish rival , that her father likes
Only for his possessions are so huge ,
Is gone with her along , and I must after ,
For love , thou know’st , is full of jealousy .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: But she loves you ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , and we are betrothed ; nay more , our marriage hour ,
With all the cunning manner of our flight
Determined of : how I must climb her window ,
The ladder made of cords , and all the means
Plotted and ’greed on for my happiness .
Good Proteus , go with me to my chamber ,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Go on before . I shall inquire you forth .
I must unto the road to disembark
Some necessaries that I needs must use ,
And then I’ll presently attend you .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Will you make haste ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I will .
Even as one heat another heat expels ,
Or as one nail by strength drives out another ,
So the remembrance of my former love
Is by a newer object quite forgotten .
Is it mine eye , or Valentine’s praise ,
Her true perfection , or my false transgression ,
That makes me reasonless to reason thus ?
She is fair , and so is Julia that I love —
That I did love , for now my love is thawed ,
Which like a waxen image ’gainst a fire
Bears no impression of the thing it was .
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold ,
And that I love him not as I was wont .
O , but I love his lady too too much ,
And that’s the reason I love him so little .
How shall I dote on her with more advice
That thus without advice begin to love her ?
’Tis but her picture I have yet beheld ,
And that hath dazzled my reason’s light ;
But when I look on her perfections ,
There is no reason but I shall be blind .
If I can check my erring love , I will ;
If not , to compass her I’ll use my skill .

stage.hi: Enter Speed and Lance , with his dog , Crab .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Lance , by mine honesty , welcome to Padua .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Forswear not thyself , sweet youth , for I am not
welcome . I reckon this always : that a man is never
undone till he be hanged , nor never welcome to a
place till some certain shot be paid and the Hostess
say welcome .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Come on , you madcap . I’ll to the alehouse with
you presently , where , for one shot of five pence ,
thou shalt have five thousand welcomes . But , sirrah ,
how did thy master part with Madam Julia ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Marry , after they closed in earnest , they parted
very fairly in jest .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: But shall she marry him ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: No .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: How then ? Shall he marry her ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: No , neither .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: What , are they broken ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: No , they are both as whole as a fish .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why then , how stands the matter with them ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Marry , thus : when it stands well with him , it
stands well with her .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: What an ass art thou ! I understand thee not .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: What a block art thou that thou canst not ! My
staff understands me .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: What thou sayst ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Ay , and what I do too . Look thee , I’ll but lean ,
and my staff understands me .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: It stands under thee indeed .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , “ stand under ” and “ understand ” is all
one .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: But tell me true , will ’t be a match ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Ask my dog . If he say “ Ay , ” it will ; if he say
“ No , ” it will ; if he shake his tail and say nothing , it
will .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: The conclusion is , then , that it will .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but
by a parable .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: ’Tis well that I get it so . But , Lance , how sayst
thou that my master is become a notable lover ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: I never knew him otherwise .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Than how ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: A notable lubber , as thou reportest him to be .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , thou whoreson ass , thou mistak’st me .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , fool , I meant not thee ; I meant thy master .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: I tell thee , my master is become a hot lover .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , I tell thee , I care not though he burn
himself in love . If thou wilt , go with me to the
alehouse ; if not , thou art an Hebrew , a Jew , and not
worth the name of a Christian .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee
as to go to the ale with a Christian . Wilt thou go ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: At thy service .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: To leave my Julia , shall I be forsworn .
To love fair Sylvia , shall I be forsworn .
To wrong my friend , I shall be much forsworn .
And ev’n that power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury .
Love bade me swear , and love bids me forswear .
O sweet-suggesting Love , if thou hast sinned ,
Teach me , thy tempted subject , to excuse it .
At first I did adore a twinkling star ,
But now I worship a celestial sun ;
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken ,
And he wants wit that wants resolvèd will
To learn his wit t’ exchange the bad for better .
Fie , fie , unreverend tongue , to call her bad
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferred
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths .
I cannot leave to love , and yet I do .
But there I leave to love where I should love .
Julia I lose , and Valentine I lose ;
If I keep them , I needs must lose myself ;
If I lose them , thus find I by their loss :
For Valentine , myself ; for Julia , Sylvia .
I to myself am dearer than a friend ,
For love is still most precious in itself ,
And Sylvia — witness heaven that made her fair —
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope .
I will forget that Julia is alive ,
Rememb’ring that my love to her is dead ;
And Valentine I’ll hold an enemy ,
Aiming at Sylvia as a sweeter friend .
I cannot now prove constant to myself
Without some treachery used to Valentine .
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Sylvia’s chamber window ,
Myself in counsel his competitor .
Now presently I’ll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight ,
Who , all enraged , will banish Valentine ,
For Thurio he intends shall wed his daughter .
But Valentine being gone , I’ll quickly cross
By some sly trick blunt Thurio’s dull proceeding .
Love , lend me wings to make my purpose swift ,
As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Counsel , Lucetta . Gentle girl , assist me ;
And ev’n in kind love I do conjure thee —
Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly charactered and engraved —
To lesson me and tell me some good mean
How with my honor I may undertake
A journey to my loving Proteus .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Alas , the way is wearisome and long .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps ;
Much less shall she that hath Love’s wings to fly ,
And when the flight is made to one so dear ,
Of such divine perfection , as Sir Proteus .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Better forbear till Proteus make return .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: O , know’st thou not his looks are my soul’s food ?
Pity the dearth that I have pinèd in
By longing for that food so long a time .
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love ,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of love with words .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: I do not seek to quench your love’s hot fire ,
But qualify the fire’s extreme rage ,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: The more thou damm’st it up , the more it burns .
The current that with gentle murmur glides ,
Thou know’st , being stopped , impatiently doth rage ,
But when his fair course is not hinderèd ,
He makes sweet music with th’ enameled stones ,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage ;
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild ocean .
Then let me go and hinder not my course .
I’ll be as patient as a gentle stream
And make a pastime of each weary step
Till the last step have brought me to my love ,
And there I’ll rest as after much turmoil
A blessèd soul doth in Elysium .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: But in what habit will you go along ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Not like a woman , for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men .
Gentle Lucetta , fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well-reputed page .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Why , then , your Ladyship must cut your hair .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: No , girl , I’ll knit it up in silken strings
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots .
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: What fashion , madam , shall I make your breeches ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: That fits as well as “ Tell me , good my lord ,
What compass will you wear your farthingale ? ”
Why , ev’n what fashion thou best likes , Lucetta .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: You must needs have them with a codpiece , madam .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Out , out , Lucetta . That will be ill-favored .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: A round hose , madam , now’s not worth a pin
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Lucetta , as thou lov’st me , let me have
What thou think’st meet and is most mannerly .
But tell me , wench , how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey ?
I fear me it will make me scandalized .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: If you think so , then stay at home and go not .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Nay , that I will not .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Then never dream on infamy , but go .
If Proteus like your journey when you come ,
No matter who’s displeased when you are gone .
I fear me he will scarce be pleased withal .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: That is the least , Lucetta , of my fear .
A thousand oaths , an ocean of his tears ,
And instances of infinite of love
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: All these are servants to deceitful men .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Base men that use them to so base effect !
But truer stars did govern Proteus’ birth .
His words are bonds , his oaths are oracles ,
His love sincere , his thoughts immaculate ,
His tears pure messengers sent from his heart ,
His heart as far from fraud as heaven from Earth .

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.l: Pray heav’n he prove so when you come to him .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.l: Now , as thou lov’st me , do him not that wrong
To bear a hard opinion of his truth .
Only deserve my love by loving him .
And presently go with me to my chamber
To take a note of what I stand in need of
To furnish me upon my longing journey .
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose ,
My goods , my lands , my reputation .
Only , in lieu thereof , dispatch me hence .
Come , answer not , but to it presently .
I am impatient of my tarriance .

div.head: Scene 1

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Sir Thurio , give us leave , I pray , awhile ;
We have some secrets to confer about .
Now tell me , Proteus , what’s your will with me ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: My gracious lord , that which I would discover
The law of friendship bids me to conceal ,
But when I call to mind your gracious favors
Done to me , undeserving as I am ,
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else no worldly good should draw from me .
Know , worthy prince , Sir Valentine my friend
This night intends to steal away your daughter ;
Myself am one made privy to the plot .
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio , whom your gentle daughter hates ,
And should she thus be stol’n away from you ,
It would be much vexation to your age .
Thus , for my duty’s sake , I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift
Than , by concealing it , heap on your head
A pack of sorrows which would press you down ,
Being unprevented , to your timeless grave .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Proteus , I thank thee for thine honest care ,
Which to requite command me while I live .
This love of theirs myself have often seen ,
Haply when they have judged me fast asleep ,
And oftentimes have purposed to forbid
Sir Valentine her company and my court .
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
And so , unworthily , disgrace the man —
A rashness that I ever yet have shunned —
I gave him gentle looks , thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me .
And that thou mayst perceive my fear of this ,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested ,
I nightly lodge her in an upper tower ,
The key whereof myself have ever kept ,
And thence she cannot be conveyed away .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Know , noble lord , they have devised a mean
How he her chamber-window will ascend
And with a corded ladder fetch her down ;
For which the youthful lover now is gone ,
And this way comes he with it presently ,
Where , if it please you , you may intercept him .
But , good my lord , do it so cunningly
That my discovery be not aimèd at ;
For love of you , not hate unto my friend ,
Hath made me publisher of this pretense .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Upon mine honor , he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Adieu , my lord . Sir Valentine is coming .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Sir Valentine , whither away so fast ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Please it your Grace , there is a messenger
That stays to bear my letters to my friends ,
And I am going to deliver them .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Be they of much import ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: The tenor of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Nay then , no matter . Stay with me awhile ;
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near , wherein thou must be secret .
’Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I know it well , my lord , and sure the match
Were rich and honorable . Besides , the gentleman
Is full of virtue , bounty , worth , and qualities
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter .
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: No . Trust me , she is peevish , sullen , froward ,
Proud , disobedient , stubborn , lacking duty ,
Neither regarding that she is my child
Nor fearing me as if I were her father ;
And may I say to thee , this pride of hers ,
Upon advice , hath drawn my love from her ,
And where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherished by her childlike duty ,
I now am full resolved to take a wife
And turn her out to who will take her in .
Then let her beauty be her wedding dower ,
For me and my possessions she esteems not .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What would your Grace have me to do in this ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: There is a lady in Verona here
Whom I affect ; but she is nice , and coy ,
And nought esteems my agèd eloquence .
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor —
For long agone I have forgot to court ;
Besides , the fashion of the time is changed —
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Win her with gifts if she respect not words ;
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman’s mind .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: But she did scorn a present that I sent her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: A woman sometime scorns what best contents her .
Send her another ; never give her o’er ,
For scorn at first makes after-love the more .
If she do frown , ’tis not in hate of you ,
But rather to beget more love in you .
If she do chide , ’tis not to have you gone ,
Forwhy the fools are mad if left alone .
Take no repulse , whatever she doth say ;
For “ get you gone ” she doth not mean “ away . ”
Flatter and praise , commend , extol their graces ;
Though ne’er so black , say they have angels’ faces .
That man that hath a tongue , I say , is no man
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: But she I mean is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth
And kept severely from resort of men ,
That no man hath access by day to her .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , then , I would resort to her by night .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Ay , but the doors be locked and keys kept safe ,
That no man hath recourse to her by night .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: What lets but one may enter at her window ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Her chamber is aloft , far from the ground ,
And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , then a ladder quaintly made of cords
To cast up , with a pair of anchoring hooks ,
Would serve to scale another Hero’s tower ,
So bold Leander would adventure it .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Now , as thou art a gentleman of blood ,
Advise me where I may have such a ladder .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: When would you use it ? Pray sir , tell me that .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This very night ; for love is like a child
That longs for everything that he can come by .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: By seven o’clock I’ll get you such a ladder .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: But hark thee : I will go to her alone ;
How shall I best convey the ladder thither ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: It will be light , my lord , that you may bear it
Under a cloak that is of any length .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Ay , my good lord .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Then let me see thy cloak ;
I’ll get me one of such another length .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Why , any cloak will serve the turn , my lord .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak ?
I pray thee , let me feel thy cloak upon me .

stage.hi: Pulling off the cloak , he reveals a rope ladder and a paper .

sp.l:
What letter is this same ? What’s here ? ( Reads . )
To Sylvia .
And here an engine fit for my proceeding .
I’ll be so bold to break the seal for once .
My thoughts do harbor with my Sylvia nightly ,
And slaves they are to me that send them flying .
O , could their master come and go as lightly ,
Himself would lodge where , senseless , they are lying .

lg.l: My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them ,

sp.l: While I , their king , that thither them importune ,
Do curse the grace that with such grace hath blest them ,
Because myself do want my servants’ fortune .

lg.l: I curse myself , for they are sent by me ,
That they should harbor where their lord should be .
Sylvia , this night I will enfranchise thee .

div.l: ’Tis so . And here’s the ladder for the purpose .
Why , Phaëton — for thou art Merops’ son —
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
And with thy daring folly burn the world ?
Wilt thou reach stars because they shine on thee ?
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates
And think my patience , more than thy desert ,
Is privilege for thy departure hence .
Thank me for this more than for all the favors
Which all too much I have bestowed on thee .
But if thou linger in my territories
Will give thee time to leave our royal court ,
By heaven , my wrath shall far exceed the love
I ever bore my daughter or thyself .
Begone . I will not hear thy vain excuse ,

sp.l: But , as thou lov’st thy life , make speed from hence .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: And why not death , rather than living torment ?
To die is to be banished from myself ,
And Sylvia is myself ; banished from her
Is self from self — a deadly banishment .
What light is light if Sylvia be not seen ?
What joy is joy if Sylvia be not by —
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection ?
Except I be by Sylvia in the night ,
There is no music in the nightingale .
Unless I look on Sylvia in the day ,
There is no day for me to look upon .
She is my essence , and I leave to be
If I be not by her fair influence
Fostered , illumined , cherished , kept alive .
I fly not death , to fly his deadly doom ;
Tarry I here , I but attend on death ,
But fly I hence , I fly away from life .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Run , boy , run , run , and seek him out .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: So-ho , so-ho !

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: What seest thou ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Him we go to find . There’s not a hair on ’s head
but ’tis a Valentine .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Valentine ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Who then ? His spirit ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Neither .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: What then ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Nothing .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Can nothing speak ? Master , shall I strike ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Who wouldst thou strike ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Nothing .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Villain , forbear .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , sir , I’ll strike nothing . I pray you —

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Sirrah , I say forbear . — Friend Valentine , a word .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: My ears are stopped and cannot hear good news ,
So much of bad already hath possessed them .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine ,
For they are harsh , untunable , and bad .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Is Sylvia dead ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: No , Valentine .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No Valentine indeed for sacred Sylvia .
Hath she forsworn me ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: No , Valentine .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No Valentine if Sylvia have forsworn me .
What is your news ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Sir , there is a proclamation that you are
vanished .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: That thou art banishèd — O , that’s the news —
From hence , from Sylvia , and from me thy friend .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: O , I have fed upon this woe already ,
And now excess of it will make me surfeit .
Doth Sylvia know that I am banishèd ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Ay , ay , and she hath offered to the doom —
Which unreversed stands in effectual force —
A sea of melting pearl , which some call tears ;
Those at her father’s churlish feet she tendered ,
With them , upon her knees , her humble self ,
Wringing her hands , whose whiteness so became them
As if but now they waxèd pale for woe .
But neither bended knees , pure hands held up ,
Sad sighs , deep groans , nor silver-shedding tears
Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire ;
But Valentine , if he be ta’en , must die .
Besides , her intercession chafed him so ,
When she for thy repeal was suppliant ,
That to close prison he commanded her
With many bitter threats of biding there .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: No more , unless the next word that thou speak’st
Have some malignant power upon my life .
If so , I pray thee breathe it in mine ear
As ending anthem of my endless dolor .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help ,
And study help for that which thou lament’st .
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good .
Here , if thou stay , thou canst not see thy love ;
Besides , thy staying will abridge thy life .
Hope is a lover’s staff ; walk hence with that
And manage it against despairing thoughts .
Thy letters may be here , though thou art hence ,
Which , being writ to me , shall be delivered
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love .
The time now serves not to expostulate .
Come , I’ll convey thee through the city gate
And , ere I part with thee , confer at large
Of all that may concern thy love affairs .
As thou lov’st Sylvia , though not for thyself ,
Regard thy danger , and along with me .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: I pray thee , Lance , an if thou seest my boy ,
Bid him make haste and meet me at the North Gate .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Go , sirrah , find him out . — Come , Valentine .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: O , my dear Sylvia ! Hapless Valentine !

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: I am but a fool , look you , and yet I have the wit
to think my master is a kind of a knave , but that’s all
one if he be but one knave . He lives not now that
knows me to be in love , yet I am in love , but a team
of horse shall not pluck that from me , nor who ’tis I
love ; and yet ’tis a woman , but what woman I will
not tell myself ; and yet ’tis a milk-maid ; yet ’tis not a
maid , for she hath had gossips ; yet ’tis a maid , for
she is her master’s maid and serves for wages . She
hath more qualities than a water spaniel , which is
much in a bare Christian .

stage.hi: He takes out a piece of paper .

sp.l: Here is the catalog of her condition .
( Reads . ) Imprimis , She can fetch and carry . Why , a
horse can do no more ; nay , a horse cannot fetch but
only carry ; therefore is she better than a jade .
Item , She can milk . Look you , a sweet
virtue in a maid with clean hands .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: How now , Signior Lance ? What news with your
Mastership ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: With my master’s ship ? Why , it is at sea .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Well , your old vice still : mistake the word . What
news , then , in your paper ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: The black’st news that ever thou heard’st .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Why , man ? How black ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , as black as ink .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Let me read them .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Fie on thee , jolt-head , thou canst not read .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Thou liest . I can .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: I will try thee . Tell me this , who begot thee ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Marry , the son of my grandfather .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: O , illiterate loiterer , it was the son of thy grandmother .
This proves that thou canst not read .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Come , fool , come . Try me in thy paper .

sp.speaker: LANCE , giving him the paper
sp.l: There , and Saint Nicholas
be thy speed .

sp.speaker: SPEED reads
sp.l: Imprimis , She can milk .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Ay , that she can .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She brews good ale .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: And thereof comes the proverb : “ Blessing of
your heart , you brew good ale . ”

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She can sew .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: That’s as much as to say “ Can she so ? ”

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She can knit .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: What need a man care for a stock with a wench ,
when she can knit him a stock ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She can wash and scour .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: A special virtue , for then she need not be
washed and scoured .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She can spin .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Then may I set the world on wheels , when she
can spin for her living .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She hath many nameless virtues .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: That’s as much as to say “ bastard virtues , ” that
indeed know not their fathers and therefore have no
names .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Here follow her vices .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Close at the heels of her virtues .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She is not to be kissed fasting in respect of her breath .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Well , that fault may be mended with a breakfast .
Read on .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She hath a sweet mouth .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: That makes amends for her sour breath .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She doth talk in her sleep .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: It’s no matter for that , so she sleep not in her
talk .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She is slow in words .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: O villain , that set this down among her vices ! To
be slow in words is a woman’s only virtue . I pray
thee , out with ’t , and place it for her chief virtue .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She is proud .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Out with that too ; it was Eve’s legacy and
cannot be ta’en from her .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She hath no teeth .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: I care not for that neither , because I love crusts .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She is curst .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Well , the best is , she hath no teeth to bite .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She will often praise her liquor .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: If her liquor be good , she shall ; if she will not , I
will , for good things should be praised .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She is too liberal .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Of her tongue she cannot , for that’s writ down
she is slow of ; of her purse she shall not , for that I’ll
keep shut ; now , of another thing she may , and that
cannot I help . Well , proceed .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l:
Item , She hath more hair than wit , and more
faults than hairs , and more wealth than faults .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Stop there . I’ll have her . She was mine and not
mine twice or thrice in that last article . Rehearse
that once more .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: Item , She hath more hair than wit .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: “ More hair than wit ”
? It may be ; I’ll prove it :
the cover of the salt hides the salt , and therefore it is
more than the salt ; the hair that covers the wit is
more than the wit , for the greater hides the less .
What’s next ?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And more faults than hairs .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: That’s monstrous ! O , that that were out !

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And more wealth than faults .

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , that word makes the faults gracious . Well ,
I’ll have her , and if it be a match , as nothing is
impossible —

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: What then ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Why , then will I tell thee that thy master stays
for thee at the North Gate .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: For me ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: For thee ? Ay , who art thou ? He hath stayed for a
better man than thee .

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.l: And must I go to him ?

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Thou must run to him , for thou hast stayed so
long that going will scarce serve the turn .

sp.speaker: SPEED , handing him the paper
sp.l: Why didst not tell me
sooner ? Pox of your love letters !

sp.speaker: LANCE
sp.l: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter ;
an unmannerly slave , that will thrust himself into
secrets . I’ll after , to rejoice in the boy’s correction .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Sir Thurio , fear not but that she will love you
Now Valentine is banished from her sight .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: Since his exile she hath despised me most ,
Forsworn my company and railed at me ,
That I am desperate of obtaining her .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenchèd in ice , which with an hour’s heat
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form .
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts ,
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot .
How now , Sir Proteus ? Is your countryman ,
According to our proclamation , gone ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Gone , my good lord .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: My daughter takes his going grievously .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: A little time , my lord , will kill that grief .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: So I believe , but Thurio thinks not so .
Proteus , the good conceit I hold of thee ,
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert ,
Makes me the better to confer with thee .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Longer than I prove loyal to your Grace
Let me not live to look upon your Grace .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Thou know’st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: I do , my lord .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: And also , I think , thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: She did , my lord , when Valentine was here .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Ay , and perversely she persevers so .
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine , and love Sir Thurio ?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood , cowardice , and poor descent ,
Three things that women highly hold in hate .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Ay , but she’ll think that it is spoke in hate .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Ay , if his enemy deliver it .
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one whom she esteemeth as his friend .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Then you must undertake to slander him .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: And that , my lord , I shall be loath to do .
’Tis an ill office for a gentleman ,
Especially against his very friend .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Where your good word cannot advantage him ,
Your slander never can endamage him ;
Therefore the office is indifferent ,
Being entreated to it by your friend .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: You have prevailed , my lord . If I can do it
By aught that I can speak in his dispraise ,
She shall not long continue love to him .
But say this weed her love from Valentine ,
It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio .

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.l: Therefore , as you unwind her love from him ,
Lest it should ravel and be good to none ,
You must provide to bottom it on me ,
Which must be done by praising me as much
As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: And , Proteus , we dare trust you in this kind
Because we know , on Valentine’s report ,
You are already Love’s firm votary
And cannot soon revolt and change your mind .
Upon this warrant shall you have access
Where you with Sylvia may confer at large —
For she is lumpish , heavy , melancholy ,
And , for your friend’s sake , will be glad of you —
Where you may temper her by your persuasion
To hate young Valentine and love my friend .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: As much as I can do I will effect . —
But you , Sir Thurio , are not sharp enough .
You must lay lime to tangle her desires
By wailful sonnets , whose composèd rhymes
Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Ay , much is the force of heaven-bred poesy .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears , your sighs , your heart .
Write till your ink be dry , and with your tears
Moist it again , and frame some feeling line
That may discover such integrity .
For Orpheus’ lute was strung with poets’ sinews ,
Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones ,
Make tigers tame , and huge leviathans
Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands .
After your dire-lamenting elegies ,
Visit by night your lady’s chamber window
With some sweet consort ; to their instruments
Tune a deploring dump ; the night’s dead silence
Will well become such sweet complaining grievance .
This , or else nothing , will inherit her .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This discipline shows thou hast been in love .

sp.speaker: THURIO , to Proteus
sp.l: And thy advice this night I’ll put in practice .
Therefore , sweet Proteus , my direction-giver ,
Let us into the city presently
To sort some gentlemen well-skilled in music .
I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advice .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: About it , gentlemen .

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.l: We’ll wait upon your Grace till after supper
And afterward determine our proceedings .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Even now about it ! I will pardon you .

sp.speaker: FIRST OUTLAW
sp.l: Fellows , stand fast . I see a passenger .

sp.speaker: SECOND OUTLAW
sp.l: If there be ten , shrink not , but down with ’em .

sp.speaker: THIRD OUTLAW
sp.l: Stand , sir , and throw us that you have about you .
If not , we’ll make you sit , and rifle you .

sp.speaker: SPEED , to Valentine
sp.l: Sir , we are undone ; these are the villains
That all the travelers do fear so much .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: My friends —

sp.speaker: FIRST OUTLAW
sp.l: That’s not so , sir . We are your enemies .

sp.speaker: SECOND OUTLAW
sp.l: Peace . We’ll hear him .

sp.speaker: THIRD OUTLAW
sp.l: Ay , by my beard , will we , for he is a proper man .

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: Then know that I have little wealth to lose .
A man I am crossed with adversity ;
My riches are these poor habiliments ,
Of which , if you should here disfurnish me ,
You take the sum and substance that I have .

sp.speaker: SECOND OUTLAW
sp.l: Whither travel you ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: To Verona .

sp.speaker: FIRST OUTLAW
sp.l: Whence came you ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: From Milan .

sp.speaker: THIRD OUTLAW
sp.l: Have you long sojourned there ?
